Publ. 1996; 139: 47-59PubMed Google Scholar).Retinoids act through binding to nuclear receptors that belong to the steroid/thyroid hormone superfamily. It has been proposed that target genes are regulated by these receptors that act as transcription factors activated by retinoids (3DeLuca L.M. FASEB J. 1991; 5: 2924-2933Crossref PubMed Scopus (812) Google Scholar, 4van der Saag P.T. Eur. J. Clin. Nutr. 1996; 50: 24-28PubMed Google Scholar, 5Botling J. Castro D.S. Oberg F. Nilsson K. Perlmann T. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 9443-9449Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar, 6Leid M. Kastner P. Chambon P. Trends Biochem Sci. 1992; 17: 427-433Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (803) Google Scholar). However, there is also evidence indicating that retinoid action can be mediated through mechanisms not involving the retinoid nuclear receptors (22Chao W.R. Hobbs P.D. Jong L. Zhang X.K. Zheng Y. Wu Q. Shroot B. Dawson M.I. Cancer Lett. 1997; 115: 1-7Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar, 23Hsu C.A. Rishi A.K. Su-Li X. Gerald T.M. Dawson M.I. Schiffer C. Reichert V. Shroot B. Poirer G.C. Fontana J.A. Blood. 1997; 89: 4470-4479Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In the present study it is demonstrated that the important ribozyme RNase P isolated fromD. discoideum is competitively inhibited by natural and synthetic retinoids.All retinoids tested revealed a dose-dependent inhibition of RNase P activity, indicating that these compounds may have a direct effect on tRNA biogenesis. Detailed kinetic analysis showed that the type of inhibition of retinol, all-trans retinoic acid, isotretinoin, and acitretin is simply competitive. According to this finding we could assign the potency of inhibitors solely on the basis of the K i value. Thus, acitretin is 184, 2.5, and 1.9 times more potent than retinol, isotretinoin, and all-trans retinoic acid, respectively.An interesting observation is that substitution of the CH3O group for hydrogen in the P position of the aromatic ring of the parent compound (all-trans retinoic acid) (Fig. 1) enhances the inhibitory potency of the retinoid. Because the CH3O group increases the hydrophobicity of acitretin, it is possible that this compound may fit better into hydrophobic site(s) of the RNase P. It has been suggested that the low buoyant density of RNase P in Cs2SO4 gradients (19Stathopoulos C. Kalpaxis D.L. Drainas D. Eur. J. Biochem. 1995; 228: 976-980Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar) can be attributed to the occurrence of an unidentified component such as a fatty acid or lipid. This hypothesis is consistent with the existence of hydrophobic site(s) on RNase P. On the other hand, retinol, which is a very weak inhibitor (K i = 1475 μm), has a hydroxyl group in place of the carboxyl one (Fig. 1), indicating that the absence of the latter affects the binding of the analog with the enzyme. It is also interesting that among the stereoisomers (Fig. 1) all-trans retinoic acid (K i = 15 μm) is stronger inhibitor than isotretinoin (13-cis retinoic acid) (K i = 20 μm), suggesting that the stereochemical properties play an important role in the inhibitory behavior of these molecules.A significant point of interest emerged from the Hill plot analysis (Fig. 6). Only one binding site (n ≅ 1) for retinoids seems to be necessary for the inhibition of RNase P reaction. Because of the kinetic nature of this observation, we cannot exclude the existence of additional retinoid-binding sites on RNase P holoenzyme, which are not involved in the kinetic model of inhibition.Because the retinoids examined in the present study reveal no structural similarity to the substrate (pre-tRNA) of RNase P, the competitive character of the inhibition suggests that these compounds may bind to allosteric inhibition sites of the enzyme. Finally, it is possible that the inhibition of D. discoideum RNase P could have been caused by a retinoid-specific receptor complex; the receptor could have been co-eluted with RNase P activity during the purification procedure. However, this hypothesis can be ruled out, because RNase P activity during the purification through the Sephacryl S-300 column elutes with the void volume of the column, with the enzyme behaving as a protein with very high molecular mass (see “Materials and Methods”), whereas retinoic acid receptors, if present in the extract, will elute in later fractions well apart from the RNase P activity, because of their low molecular mass (<50 kDa) (3DeLuca L.M. FASEB J. 1991; 5: 2924-2933Crossref PubMed Scopus (812) Google Scholar). Furthermore, it could be speculated that the inhibition of RNase P activity results from retinoids titrating out a co-activator component from RNase P, for example a bivalent cation like Mg2+; nevertheless, this possibility is definitely ruled out because in this case the inhibition pattern is of partial noncompetitive type. 1A. Tekos, C. Stathopoulos, and D. Drainas, unpublished results. Moreover, other types of RNase P co-activators have not been reported so far. Fontana J.A. Blood. 1997; 89: 4470-4479Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In the present study it is demonstrated that the important ribozyme RNase P isolated fromD. discoideum is competitively inhibited by natural and synthetic retinoids. All retinoids tested revealed a dose-dependent inhibition of RNase P activity, indicating that these compounds may have a direct effect on tRNA biogenesis. Detailed kinetic analysis showed that the type of inhibition of retinol, all-trans retinoic acid, isotretinoin, and acitretin is simply competitive. According to this finding we could assign the potency of inhibitors solely on the basis of the K i value. Thus, acitretin is 184, 2.5, and 1.9 times more potent than retinol, isotretinoin, and all-trans retinoic acid, respectively. An interesting observation is that substitution of the CH3O group for hydrogen in the P position of the aromatic ring of the parent compound (all-trans retinoic acid) (Fig. 1) enhances the inhibitory potency of the retinoid. Because the CH3O group increases the hydrophobicity of acitretin, it is possible that this compound may fit better into hydrophobic site(s) of the RNase P. It has been suggested that the low buoyant density of RNase P in Cs2SO4 gradients (19Stathopoulos C. Kalpaxis D.L. Drainas D. Eur. J. Biochem. 1995; 228: 976-980Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar) can be attributed to the occurrence of an unidentified component such as a fatty acid or lipid. This hypothesis is consistent with the existence of hydrophobic site(s) on RNase P. On the other hand, retinol, which is a very weak inhibitor (K i = 1475 μm), has a hydroxyl group in place of the carboxyl one (Fig. 1), indicating that the absence of the latter affects the binding of the analog with the enzyme. It is also interesting that among the stereoisomers (Fig. 1) all-trans retinoic acid (K i = 15 μm) is stronger inhibitor than isotretinoin (13-cis retinoic acid) (K i = 20 μm), suggesting that the stereochemical properties play an important role in the inhibitory behavior of these molecules. A significant point of interest emerged from the Hill plot analysis (Fig. 6). Only one binding site (n ≅ 1) for retinoids seems to be necessary for the inhibition of RNase P reaction. Because of the kinetic nature of this observation, we cannot exclude the existence of additional retinoid-binding sites on RNase P holoenzyme, which are not involved in the kinetic model of inhibition. Because the retinoids examined in the present study reveal no structural similarity to the substrate (pre-tRNA) of RNase P, the competitive character of the inhibition suggests that these compounds may bind to allosteric inhibition sites of the enzyme. Finally, it is possible that the inhibition of D. discoideum RNase P could have been caused by a retinoid-specific receptor complex; the receptor could have been co-eluted with RNase P activity during the purification procedure. However, this hypothesis can be ruled out, because RNase P activity during the purification through the Sephacryl S-300 column elutes with the void volume of the column, with the enzyme behaving as a protein with very high molecular mass (see “Materials and Methods”), whereas retinoic acid receptors, if present in the extract, will elute in later fractions well apart from the RNase P activity, because of their low molecular mass (<50 kDa) (3DeLuca L.M. FASEB J. 1991; 5: 2924-2933Crossref PubMed Scopus (812) Google Scholar). Furthermore, it could be speculated that the inhibition of RNase P activity results from retinoids titrating out a co-activator component from RNase P, for example a bivalent cation like Mg2+; nevertheless, this possibility is definitely ruled out because in this case the inhibition pattern is of partial noncompetitive type. 1A. Tekos, C. Stathopoulos, and D. Drainas, unpublished results. Moreover, other types of RNase P co-activators have not been reported so far. We thank Dr. D. L. Kalpaxis for critical reading of the manuscript.

The addition of ATP to Mg2+-Na+-bound-probe labeled Na+,K+-ATPase preparations containing ∼0.5 mol of pyridoxal 5′-diphospho-5′-adenosine (AP2PL) probe at Lys-480 and ∼0.9 mol of fluorescein 5′-isothiocyanate (FITC) probe at Lys-501 showed a decrease and an increase in the AP2PL fluorescence intensity with neither significant ATP-dependent phosphorylation nor FITC fluorescence change. The rate constants for the fluorescence change increased nearly linearly with increasing ATP concentrations. The substitution of AcP for ATP decreased the FITC fluorescence rather monophasically, 8.5/s, which was followed by the half-site phosphorylation with same amount of components with different rate constant, 7.2 and 4.6/s, followed by a much slower increase in the two components of AP2PL fluorescence, 1.4 and 0.2/s. The addition of Na+ with increasing concentrations of ATP to the K+-bound AP2PL-FITC enzymes induced accelerations in the decrease and an increase in the AP2PL fluorescence intensity with two different increases in the FITC fluorescence intensity, showing that the same concentration of ATP is capable of inducing four different fluorescence changes. The addition of ATP to the Mg2+-Na+-bound enzymes modified withN-[p-(2-benzimidazolyl)phenyl]-maleimide (BIPM) at Cys-964 and retaining full Na+,K+-ATPase activity induced two different increases in BIPM fluorescence intensity. Each rate constant for the BIPM fluorescence change versus concentrations of ATP gave two intersecting straight lines. These data and the stoichiometries of fluorescence probe bindings and ATP- and AcP-dependent phosphorylation provide strong support for the conclusion that the functional membrane-bound Na+,K+-ATPase is a tetramer. Recently, the half-site stoichiometry for phosphorylation by ATP for the case of Na+,K+-ATPase, which is independent of specific activities, while retaining nearly full-site ATP binding capacity in the presence of CDTA1 (18Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar) has been unequivocally demonstrated (19Tsuda T,. Kaya S. Yokoyama T. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 24334-24338Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). The data also showed that enzyme preparations that contained ∼0.5 mol of pyridoxal 5′-diphospho-5′-adenosine (AP2PL) probe at Lys-480 of the α-chain reduced the phosphorylation stoichiometry to ∼0.25. When the AP2PL enzymes were further treated with a fluorescein 5′-isothiocyanate (FITC), the resulting AP2PL-FITC enzymes contained ∼0.9 mol of the FITC probe at Lys-501, which reduced the value to ∼0.03. The FITC treatment had a negligible effect on the rate and the extent of individual ATP- and AcP-dependent fluorescence changes due to the AP2PL chromophore and the amount of AcP-dependent half-site phosphorylation in the presence of Mg2+ and Na+ (18Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar, 19Tsuda T,. Kaya S. Yokoyama T. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 24334-24338Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). These data are consistent with the hypothesis that phosphorylation is not required for ATP-induced AP2PL fluorescence change of the AP2PL and AP2PL-FITC enzymes and that four ATP binding sites are present in Na+,K+-ATPase. In this paper, ATP- or AcP-induced conformational events were followed by measuring fluorescence changes of the AP2PL probe at Lys-480 and the FITC probe at Lys-501 using the AP2PL-FITC enzymes. Since the N-(p-(2-benzimidazolyl)phenyl) maleimide (BIPM) treatment had little effect on both Na+,K+-ATPase activity and the phosphorylation capacity (7Nagai M. Taniguchi K. Kangawa K. Matsuo S. Nakamura S. Iida S. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 13197-13202Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), ATP-induced BIPM fluorescence changes at Cys-964 of the α-chain, which is near the transmembrane domain M9 of the enzyme (20Lutsenko S. Daoud S. Kaplan J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 5249-5255Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar), were also followed whether or not ATP induced multiple conformational changes in the BIPM enzyme. The data indicate the occurrence of four ATP binding induced out of phase fluorescence changes not only near the ATP binding domain, but also in the membrane domain. Experimental methods were exactly as described in previous papers unless otherwise indicated (18Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar, 19Tsuda T,. Kaya S. Yokoyama T. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biol. Steady-state fluorescence measurements were performed using a Shimadzu RF-503 difference spectrofluorophotometer at 25 °C (8Taniguchi K. Suzuki K. Iida S. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 10659-10667Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) with a sample of 3.2 ml (50 μg of protein/ml) under the same reaction conditions as for the Na+-ATPase measurements as described in Fig. 1 legend, except in some experiments, ATP was replaced with AcP. The fluorescence excitation was at 320 (AP2PL) and 470 (FITC) nm, and the emission was detected at 390 (AP2PL) and 520 (FITC) nm, respectively. Transient fluorescence measurements were performed using an Applied Photophysics DX 17MV stopped-flow spectrofluorimeter at 25 °C (11Taniguchi K. Mårdh S. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 15588-15594Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The experiments were started by mixing equal volumes (25 μl) of solutions as described for the Na+-ATPase measurements except that in some experiments, 16 mm NaCl was replaced with 1.6 mm KCl. In addition, one volume contained 60 μg/ml enzyme protein and the other contained various concentrations of ATP or AcP without or with 5 or 160 mm NaCl or corresponding concentrations of Tris-HCl (pH 7.4) or choline chloride as a control. The sample was excited at 305 (BIPM), 320 (AP2PL), and 470 (FITC) nm and the emission was detected at 360 (BIPM), 390 (AP2PL), and 520 (FITC) nm after passage through Nippon Shinku Kogaku interference filters as described previously (19Tsuda T,. Kaya S. Yokoyama T. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 24334-24338Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). The experiments were repeated at least 10 times. The ratios of accumulated data in the presence of substrates to those obtained for the controls were fitted to a single or a double exponential curve in order to estimate the apparent rate constants and the extent of fluorescence changes using a non-linear least squares fit analysis. The experiments were performed using several different enzyme preparations, and the data shown are typical examples. The starting positions of all the curves for transient fluorescence changes (Figs. 2 A, 3 A, 3 B, 5, 6, and 7 A) were offset in order to see the shape of each curve more clearly. The experiments were started by mixing equal volumes (60 μl) of the solutions used for the Na+-ATPase measurement except the [32P]ATP was replaced with [32P]AcP. After mixing, the reaction was quenched by adding 1 m HCl, 10 mmH3PO4, and 1 mm AcP or ATP (11Taniguchi K. Mårdh S. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 15588-15594Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Previous stopped flow experiments showed that the addition of ATP and AcP to the Mg2+-Na+-bound AP2PL-FITC enzymes containing ∼0.5 mol of AP2PL probe at Lys-480 and ∼0.9 mol of FITC probe at Lys-501/α-chain, respectively, induced a similar extent of increase in the AP2PL fluorescence intensity without and with phosphorylation (18Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). To investigate this point further, steady state fluorescence measurements were performed. The addition of 10 μm ATP to the Mg2+-Na+-bound AP2PL-FITC enzymes increased the AP2PL fluorescence with no observable FITC fluorescence change (Fig. 1 A, top and bottom). The AP2PL fluorescence decreased to the initial level over a period of time and the readdition of ATP caused a reversible increase in the fluorescence (Fig. 1 A, top). However, no significant FITC fluorescence change was observed, even after the addition of 100 μm ATP, which kept the increased level of AP2PL fluorescence up to 1 h (data not shown). The increase in AP2PL fluorescence by ATP in the presence of Mg2+ and Na+ (Fig. 1 A, top) without significant phosphorylation is indicative of an enzyme state just after ATP hydrolysis (see Ref. 18Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar and Table I of Ref.19Tsuda T,. Kaya S. Yokoyama T. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 24334-24338Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). The reason for time-dependent decrease in AP2PL fluorescence was shown to be mainly due to the decrease of ATP concentration by Na+-ATPase activity of the AP2PL-FITC enzyme preparation, which still contained ∼6% of Na+-dependent phosphorylation capacity from ATP as shown (19Tsuda T,. Kaya S. Yokoyama T. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 24334-24338Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). The addition of 1 mm AcP to the Mg2+-Na+-bound AP2PL-FITC enzymes increased AP2PL fluorescence and decreased FITC fluorescence (Fig. 1 B, top and bottom). In addition the phosphoenzyme fully accumulated to a level of ∼0.5 mol/mol of α-chain as is shown in the accompanying article (19Tsuda T,. Kaya S. Yokoyama T. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 24334-24338Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). The addition of ouabain further increased AP2PL fluorescence to accumulate ouabain-bound phosphoenzyme but had little effect on FITC fluorescence (Fig. 1 B, top and bottom). Further addition of ATP to ouabain-bound phosphoenzyme had a negligible effect on AP2PL fluorescence intensity (Fig. 1 B, top). The AP2PL fluorescence intensity at Lys-480, which accompanied the accumulation of ouabain-bound phosphoenzyme was higher than that of K+-sensitive phosphoenzyme from AcP (Fig. 1 B, top). Such a conformational difference detected by fluorescence change has not been detected with the BIPM probe at Cys-964 (8Taniguchi K. Suzuki K. Iida S. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 10659-10667Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) or the FITC probe at Lys-501 (14Yamazaki A. Kaya S. Tsuda T. Araki Y. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1994; 116: 1360-1369Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar) to date. The FITC fluorescence change induced by AcP in the presence of Mg2+ and Na+ is known to be reversible (17Taniguchi K. Kai D. Inoue S. Shinoguchi E. Sasaki T. Nakamura Y. Adachi Y. Kaya S. Bamberg E. Schoner W. The Sodium Pump: Structure, Mechanism, Hormonal Control and Its Role in Disease. Dietrich Steinkopff Verlag GmbH & Co. KG, Darmstadt, Germany1994: 581-592Crossref Google Scholar), as in the case for AP2PL fluorescence change by ATP described above. To follow the initial ATP-induced phase of the AP2PL fluorescence change of the Mg2+-Na+-bound AP2PL-FITC enzymes, various concentrations of ATP were added to the AP2PL-FITC enzyme (Fig. 2 A). The addition of 1 and 3 μm ATP induced a biphasic AP2PL fluorescence change similar to that observed for the AP2PL enzyme (19Tsuda T,. Kaya S. Yokoyama T. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 24334-24338Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar), namely a rapid decrease, followed by a slow increase. The rapid decrease apparently disappeared because of an acceleration in the slow increase in the presence of up to 10 μm ATP. However, the extent of the fluorescence increase was near saturation at around 10 μm ATP (Fig. 2 B, inset). The rate constants for the rapid decrease and the slow increase increased in a nearly linear fashion with increasing concentrations of ATP (Fig. 2 B), suggesting the participation of at least two different ATP bindings. The slopes of the two straight lines (Fig. 2 B) permitted a semiquantitative estimation of the apparent second order rate constants (k +1) to be 1.8 × 106 and 0.1 × 106m−1 s−1, respectively, for ATP for the formation of the two different conformational states with negative and positive AP2PL fluorescence intensity, compared with the Na+-bound enzyme. The dissociation rate constant (k −1) and the dissociation constant (K d =k −1/k +1) for the latter were estimated from the intercept, 0.82 s−1, and the ratio, 7.5 μm. These data suggest that at least two different ATP bindings with a ∼20-fold difference in k +1 value induced quite different AP2PL fluorescence changes in the Mg2+-Na+-bound AP2PL-FITC enzymes without significant phosphorylation (18Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar, 19Tsuda T,. Kaya S. Yokoyama T. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 24334-24338Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). ATP appears to be a better substrate than AcP in terms of increasing AP2PL fluorescence, as evidenced by the fact that eachk 1 and K d was at least 100-fold and 1/40 of that for AcP (19Tsuda T,. Kaya S. Yokoyama T. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 24334-24338Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). When the concentration of added ATP was reduced to 0.3 μmATP, the concentration of which was ∼3 fold larger than the concentration of the α-chain present (Fig. 2 A, inset), the rate constant for the decrease and the increase in AP2PL fluorescence were determined to be, respectively, 1.3/s and 0.06/s. This very slow increase seemed to be due to the slow turn over of the AP2PL-FITC enzyme just after hydrolysis of ATP (18Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar, 19Tsuda T,. Kaya S. Yokoyama T. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 24334-24338Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar) as it reached the original fluorescence level rather than to the second ATP binding-induced increase in the fluorescence, the extent of which would be higher than the initial fluorescence level as observed in the presence of up to 3 μm ATP (Fig. 2,A and B, inset, open circles). High concentrations of ATP are known to accelerate the transition of K+-bound enzyme to Na+-bound enzyme (21Karlish S.J.D. Yates D.W. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1978; 527: 115-130Crossref PubMed Scopus (185) Google Scholar). The ATP binding capacity of the AP2PL-FITC enzyme was already shown to be at least 50% of that of the control enzyme (18Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). To investigate whether ATP accelerated the transition of K+-bound AP2PL-FITC enzyme to the Na+-bound enzyme, both AP2PL and FITC fluorescence changes were followed immediately after the addition of ATP and/or Na+. The addition of 5 mm ATP induced fluorescence changes in neither AP2PL (Fig. 3 A, second trace) nor FITC (Fig. 3 B, third trace). The addition of 160 mm Na+ induced a decrease in the AP2PL fluorescence (Fig. 3 A, third trace), 3.6/s, and a biphasic increase in FITC fluorescence (Fig. 3 B, second trace), 4.4 and 0.8/s. The addition of 160 mm Na+ with 0.5 mm ATP induced a biphasic AP2PL change (Fig. 3 A, bottom), a rapid decrease (21/s), followed by a slow increase (0.7/s) with only slight effect of ATP to increase in both the extent and the rate of the FITC fluorescence (trace not shown). The extent of the initial rapid decrease in AP2PL fluorescence with increasing the concentrations of ATP could not be detected accurately due to the subsequent increase (Fig. 4 B, closed circles). The addition of 160 mm sodium with 5 mm ATP induced a monophasic increase in AP2PL fluorescence (Fig. 3 A, top), 6.4/s, with a biphasic increase in FITC fluorescence (Fig. 3 B, top), 7.0 and 1.2/s, with slight increase in the extent. Although the addition of 5 mm Na+ induced slight increases in FITC fluorescence (Fig. 3 B, bottom), the simultaneous addition of both 5 mm Na+ and 5 mmATP induced larger biphasic increases in FITC fluorescence (Fig. 3 B, fourth trace), 5.8 and 1.8/s, which showed more clearly the effects of ATP on the extent of FITC fluorescence change. Fig. 4 (A and B, respectively) shows the dependence of ATP concentration on the rate constants and the corresponding extent of both fluorescence changes in the presence of 160 mm Na+. Each rate constant for the decrease and the increase of AP2PL fluorescence increased with increasing concentrations of ATP accompanied by some deviation from linearity (Fig. 4 A, closed and open circles). The concentration dependence of ATP on FITC fluorescence changes that accompanied the transition from the K+ form to the Na+ form also suggest two different extents of ATP-induced FITC fluorescence increases with only a small increase in the rate constants (Fig. 4, A and B, open and closed triangles). These data showed that level of ATP up to submillimolar levels exerted two different actions on each of the AP2PL and FITC fluorescence changes for the K+-bound AP2PL-FITC enzymes, namely that the same concentrations of ATP resulted in four different fluorescence changes with different rate constant and/or extents. However, approximately micromolar ATP resulted in two actions on the AP2PL fluorescence change of the Na+-bound AP2PL-FITC enzymes (Fig. 2 B) with little FITC fluorescence change. To investigate the relationship between the AcP-dependent phosphorylation and fluorescence changes, 1 mm AcP was added, the concentration of which is sufficient to saturate phosphorylation (19Tsuda T,. Kaya S. Yokoyama T. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 24334-24338Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). This caused a decrease in the FITC fluorescence with rate constants of 8.5 and 1.2/s, and a decrease of 5.5 and 0.8% respectively (Fig. 5,second trace). The data could be also fitted to a single exponential curve with 7.1/s and 5.7%. Phosphorylation occurred with a rapid (7.2/s) and slow (4.6/s) phase, and showed nearly the same amount of components, namely 24 and 26%, to give half-site phosphorylation (Fig. 6, open circles), followed by two different AP2PL fluorescence increases with rate constants of 1.4 and 0.2/s and an extent of 2.4 and 0.7%, respectively (Fig. 6, top trace). Such double exponential AP2PL fluorescence changes cannot be obtained for the case of AcP-induced AP2PL fluorescence of AP2PL enzyme (19Tsuda T,. Kaya S. Yokoyama T. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 24334-24338Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (13) Google Scholar). The addition of 10 μm ATP induced neither FITC fluorescence change (Fig. 5, top) nor significant phosphorylation (18Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed

Pig and dog kidney Na+,K+-ATPase preparations, irrespective of specific activity, showed ∼0.5 mol of maximum phosphorylation/mol α-chain for ATP or acetyl phosphate (AcP) at steady state conditions. Pyridoxal 5′-diphospho-5′-adenosine (AP2PL)-treated pig kidney enzymes containing ∼0.5 mol of AP2PL probe at Lys-480/mol (Tsuda, T., Kaya, S., Funatsu, H., Hayashi, Y., and Taniguchi, K. (1998) J. Biochem. (Tokyo) 123, 169–174) showed a quarter-site phosphorylation by ATP and half-site phosphorylation from AcP. The addition of 10 μmATP to the Mg2+-Na+-bound AP2PL enzyme induced rapid quarter-site phosphorylation (47/s), followed by two different AP2PL fluorescence changes, a rapid decrease (29/s) and a slow increase (1.1/s). The addition of 1 mmAcP to the Mg2+-Na+-bound AP2PL enzyme induced a slow half-site phosphorylation (3/s), followed by a monophasic AP2PL fluorescence increase (1.2/s). After treatment of the AP2PL enzyme with fluorescein 5′-isothiocyanate to modify Lys-501 fully, the Mg2+-Na+-dependent phosphorylation capacity from ATP of the resulting AP2PL-fluorescein 5′-isothiocyanate enzyme was reduced to ∼6% without significant changes in half-site phosphorylation capacity with respect to AcP, dynamic AP2PL fluorescence change by ATP and change by AcP. These data and others support the hypothesis that the functional membrane-bound Na+,K+-ATPase has tetrameric properties. To understand the mechanism of energy transduction for this enzyme, a detailed knowledge of ATP-induced conformational changes is essential. ATP hydrolysis is accompanied by conformational changes in the enzyme, and several conformational states in the reaction cycle have been characterized using anN-(p-(2-benzimidazolyl)phenyl)maleimide (BIPM)1 probe at Cys-964 (7Nagai M. In this paper, the phosphorylation capacity of the α-chain of Na+,K+-ATPase was determined in order to compare the stoichiometry of fluorescence probes bound to the α-chain of the enzyme ∼0.5 mol of AP2PL-probe/α-chain at Lys-480 and ∼0.9 mol of FITC probe/α-chain at Lys-501 (20Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). In addition, Mg2+-, Na+-, and ATP-dependent AP2PL fluorescence changes of the probe-modified enzymes were also studied. The data are consistent with the presence of quarter-, half-, and full-site reactivities of the enzyme. Methods for the purification of Na+,K+-ATPase from pig kidney by sodium deoxycholate followed by treatment with NaI or from dog kidney by SDS treatment have been reported previously (7Nagai M. Taniguchi K. Kangawa K. Matsuo S. Nakamura S. Iida S. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 13197-13202Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 24Hayashi Y. Mimura K. Matsui H. Takagi T. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1989; 983: 217-229Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar). The specific activities of the former and the latter were ∼700–1300 and ∼2500 μmol/mg of protein/h and the Na+-dependent phosphoenzyme from ATP constituted ∼1–1.7 and ∼3.5 nmol/mg of protein, respectively. The protein concentration, Na+,K+-ATPase activity, and the amount of phosphoenzyme formed from [γ-32P]ATP or [32P]AcP were estimated as described previously (7Nagai M. Taniguchi K. Kangawa K. Matsuo S. Nakamura S. Iida S. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 13197-13202Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 17Kaya S. Tsuda T. Hagiwara K. Fukui T. Taniguchi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 7419-7422Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Na+-ATPase activity was measured in a solution containing 25 mm imidazole-HCl (pH 7.4), 4 mmMgCl2, 25 mm sucrose, 16 mm NaCl, and 0.1 mm EDTA-Tris (pH 7.4) with ∼0.5–10 μm [γ-32P]ATP with or without 100 μm ouabain for 10 min at 25 °C. The reaction was quenched by the addition of ice-cold 5% trichloroacetic acid containing 1 mm ATP and 1 mm H3PO4, followed by determination of the released32Pi (33Blostein R. Methods Enzymol. 1988; 156: 171-178Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). The phosphorylation reaction (1 mg of protein/ml) was carried out under the same conditions as were used for the Na-ATPase activity measurement except, in some experiments, the 16 mm NaCl was replaced with 2 m NaCl containing 5 μg/ml oligomycin and the incubation time was for 5 s at 0 °C using 10–2700 μm [γ-32P]ATP. The reaction was quenched with four volumes of ice-cold 10% trichloroacetic acid containing 1 mm ATP and 1 mm H3PO4by a manual method. The time course for phosphoenzyme formation was followed using a Bio-Logic Quench-Flow Module (QFM-5) at 25 °C. The experiments were started by mixing equal volumes (60 μl) of the solution for the Na+-ATPase measurement. In addition, one volume contained 0.5 mg/ml enzyme protein and the other volume contained 2 mm [32P]AcP or 20 μm [γ-32P]ATP. After mixing, the reaction was quenched by 1 m HCl, 10 mmH3PO4, and 1 mm AcP or ATP. The denatured phosphoenzyme was washed on a glass fiber filter, and the amount of phosphoenzyme was determined (11Taniguchi K. Mårdh S. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 15588-15594Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). To estimate the content of phosphorylated α-chain, the denatured enzyme was precipitated by centrifugation at 50,000 rpm for 5 min at 4 °C (Optima, TLA 100.3, Beckman) and the pellet suspended in ice-cold distilled water and centrifuged a second time. The addition of 4% (LDS) containing 50 mm CH3COOLi (pH 4.2) and 100 mm Li2SO4 (34Barrabin H. Scofano H.M. Inesi G. Biochemistry. 1984; 23: 1542-1548Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar) solubilized up to 90% of the radioactivity. The supernatant was applied to a Superdex-200 gel filtration column (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech, 1.6 × 60 cm) equilibrated with elution buffer 50 mmCH3COOLi (pH 4.2) containing 100 mmLi2SO4, 1 mmH3PO4, and 1% LDS. The radioactivity and absorbance at 280 nm were measured in each 0.75-ml fraction collected at a flow rate of 1 ml/min at 4 °C. The content of phosphorylated α-chain was calculated by the ratio of the amount of phosphorylated α-chain, estimated from the specific activity of 32P bound to the α-chain, to the total amount of α-chain, which was determined from the absorbance at 280 nm using an extinction coefficient of 109.765 m−1cm1 (35Takagi T. Maezawa S. Hayashi Y. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1987; 101: 805-811Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). Methods for the modification of pig kidney Na+,K+-ATPase preparation (1 mg/ml) with 50 μm AP2PL in 40 mm Hepes-NaOH (pH 7.8) for 10 min at 25 °C, followed by reductive fixation of reagents to the enzyme, have been reported previously (17Kaya S. Tsuda T. Hagiwara K. Fukui T. Taniguchi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 7419-7422Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The resulting AP2PL enzyme (1 mg/ml) was further treated with 15 μm FITC in a mixture containing 100 mmTris-HCl (pH 9.2) for 30 min at 25 °C (20Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). The resulting doubly modified enzyme was used as the AP2PL-FITC enzyme. The amount of AP2PL or FITC probe bound to the α-chain was determined as described previously (20Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). Transient fluorescence measurements were performed using an Applied Photophysics DX 17MV stopped-flow spectrofluorimeter at 25 °C (11Taniguchi K. Mårdh S. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 15588-15594Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The experiments were started by mixing equal volumes (25 μl) of a solution as described for the Na+-ATPase measurements. In addition, one volume contained 60 μg/ml enzyme protein and the other volume contained various concentrations of ATP or AcP or corresponding concentrations of Tris-HCl (pH 7.4) as a control. The sample was excited at 320 (AP2PL) nm, and the emission was detected at 390 (AP2PL) nm after passage through Nippon Shinku Kogaku interference filters, which allowed maximum transmittance at 390 nm. The reactions were repeated at least 10 times. The ratios of accumulated data in the presence of substrates to those obtained for the controls were fitted as a single or a double exponential curve to estimate the apparent rate constants and the extent of fluorescence changes using non-linear least squares fit analysis. The experiments were performed with several different enzyme preparations, and the data shown are typical examples. The enzymatic synthesis of [32P]AcP from [32P]phosphoric acid and the preparation of pyridoxal 5′-diphospho-5′-adenosine (AP2PL) was performed as described earlier (17Kaya S. Tsuda T. Hagiwara K. Fukui T. Taniguchi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 7419-7422Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). FITC (Type I) was purchased from Dojin Chemical Institute, Kumamoto, Japan. AcP was purchased from Sigma and converted to the Tris form. The [γ-32P]ATP and [32P]phosphoric acid were purchased from Amersham Pharmacia Biotech. All other chemicals used were of the highest grade commercially available. Chemical modifications of Na+,K+-ATPase with AP2PL and FITC (20Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar) suggested a half-site reactivity for Lys-480 with respect to AP2PL and all site reactivity for Lys-501 with respect to FITC in the catalytic subunits of the enzyme. To determine the stoichiometry of the amount of bound probes and phosphorylation capacity/α-chain, phosphorylated α-chains were isolated using a Superdex 200 (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) gel filtration column in order to measure the amount directly. These values were compared with the amount of phosphoenzyme/mg protein evaluated by the membrane filtration method (7Nagai M. Taniguchi K. Kangawa K. Matsuo S. Nakamura S. Iida S. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 13197-13202Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). To fully phosphorylate pig kidney enzymes under steady state conditions, phosphorylation reactions were carried out for 5 s at 0 °C with increasing concentrations of ATP in the presence of 4 mm Mg2+, 2m Na+, and 5 μg/ml oligomycin in order to block completely the transition of E1P to E2P (36Taniguchi K. Suzuki K. Sasaki T. Shimokobe H. Iida S. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 3272-3281Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The membrane filtration method showed that 10 μmATP gave nearly the saturation level (1.2 nmol/mg of protein) for phosphorylation (Fig. 1 A). Dog kidney enzymes, which showed 3.5 nmol of phosphoenzyme/mg of protein by the membrane filtration method, were phosphorylated and the phosphoenzymes precipitated and solubilized with LDS, and the resulting supernatant was subjected to column separation. A major single peak with both radioactivity and UV absorption appeared showing a maximum value at fraction 73 (Fig. 1 B). The ratio of the amount of phosphorylated α-chain to that of total α-chain was calculated from each fraction (Fig. 1 B, triangles, 64–83). This ratio increased with increasing the fraction numbers, reaching a maximum constant value ∼0.51 ± 0.02 mol/mol α-chain (fractions 69–78) and then decreasing. The fractions giving a ratio of ∼0.5 contained only α-chains, as determined by SDS gel electrophoresis (not shown). The data indicated the fractions contained equal amount of phosphorylated and nonphosphorylated α-chains. Neither significant radioactive peaks for either ATP or Piwere detected in fractions containing cold ATP and Pi (not shown). Four different enzyme preparations from kidneys of pigs and dogs, which maximally accumulated 1∼3.6 nmol of phosphoenzyme/mg of membrane protein, gave a value of 0.49 ± 0.03 mol/mol of α-chain. When the phosphoenzymes were formed in the presence of 4 mmMg2+ and 16 mm Na+, in the absence of oligomycin (Fig. 1 A, open circle), the amount of phosphoenzyme decreased to 75% of the maximum. The amount of isolated phosphorylated α-chain from the peak fractions was ∼0.37 mol/mol of α-chain, also suggesting that the maximum phosphorylation capacity is ∼0.5 (= ∼0.37/0.75) mol/mol of α-chain after correction for a phosphorylation level of 75%. The overall recovery of the radioactivity from the phosphoenzymes obtained by the membrane filtration method to the radioactivity of the α-chain fraction were consistently near 80%. These data suggest that only 50% of the α-chain could be phosphorylated under conditions of maximum phosphorylation from the ATP independent of the specific activity of the enzyme preparations investigated. It has been reported previously (20Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar) that the AP2PL modified enzymes contained ∼0.5 mol of AP2PL probe at Lys-480/mol of α-chain and retained ∼50% of Na+,K+-ATPase activity and that the AP2PL-FITC modified enzyme contained ∼0.9 mol of FITC probe at Lys-501/mol of α-chain and retained only ∼5% of Na+,K+-ATPase activity. Steady state phosphorylation levels and the rate and extent of AP2PL fluorescence changes of the AP2PL enzymes and AP2PL-FITC enzymes were measured after the addition of 10 μm ATP or 1 mm AcP (Table I). The data showed that AP2PL modification and the AP2PL-FITC modification reduced the amount of phosphoenzymes from ATP to 50 and 6%, respectively, indicating that ∼0.5 mol of AP2PL probe binding at Lys-480 and ∼0.9 mol of FITC probe binding/α-chain reduced the value (in moles of ATP-dependent phosphorylation/mol of α-chain) from 0.5 to 0.25 and 0.03 (Fig. 1 B), with little influence on the half-site phosphorylation by AcP (Table I) and full-site ouabain binding in the presence of Mg2+ and Pi as reported previously (27Yamazaki A. The Na+-ATPase activity of the control, AP2PL-, and AP2PL-FITC enzyme was, respectively, 1.7, 0.90, and 0.13 μmol/mg/h, and the amount of Na+-dependent phosphoenzyme of corresponding sample was 1.3, 0.65, and 0.08 nmol/mg protein. Numbers shown are means and standard deviations of the results of three independent experiments. Stopped-flow measurements showed that the addition of 10 μm ATP to the AP2PL enzyme and AP2PL-FITC enzyme preparations, respectively, in the presence of 4 mm Mg2+ and 16 mmNa+ increased the AP2PL fluorescence intensity to ∼3% despite 50 and 94% reduction in phosphorylation by ATP (Table I). The addition of 1 mm AcP to these preparations also increased the fluorescence to nearly the same level with little change in the maximum phosphorylation capacity (Table I). The concentration dependence of ATP on Na+-ATPase activity of the AP2PL enzyme and AP2PL-FITC enzyme showed that the modification reduced the V maxfrom 1.7 to 0.9 and 0.13 μmol of ATP/mg of protein/h with little change in the K m of ∼0.7 μm. The apparent turnover number of Na+-ATPase, the ratio of the ATPase activity to the amount of phosphoenzyme from ATP, was 0.35, 0.39, and 0.48/s for the control, the AP2PL enzyme and the AP2PL-FITC enzyme, respectively. Concentration dependence of ATP, Na+, and K+ on Na+,K+-ATPase activity of the AP2PL enzyme also showed K 0.5 values similar to those of controls: ∼0.8, ∼8, and ∼1.3 mm, respectively. The data suggested that AP2PL modification of Na+,K+-ATPase has no effect on any substrate affinity. However, further experiments in the presence of lower concentrations of ATP are needed, because the rate of ATP-dependent phosphorylation seemed to reduce slightly after AP2PL treatment as shown later (Fig. 2, inset). To further investigate the ATP-induced conformation change, 1, 3, and 10 μm ATP were added to the AP2PL enzyme, respectively, which induced a slow monophasic decrease, a rapid decrease followed by an increase, and then a very rapid decrease, followed by a large monophasic increase (Fig. 2, third, second, and top trace). The data show that low and high concentrations of ATP induced quite different fluorescence changes. Such changes require the simultaneous presence of ATP and Na+ with Mg2+ or Ca2+ (not shown). ATP could not be replaced with AMP-PNP or ADP (Fig. 2,fourth and fifth trace). To investigate the relationship between fluorescence change and the extent of ATP induced phosphorylation remaining, rapid-quenching experiments were performed. The addition of 10 μm[γ-32P]ATP induced a rapid phosphorylation (47/s) to give 0.8 mol of phosphoenzyme/mg of protein (Fig. 2, inset, open circles), followed by a decrease (29/s) and slower increase (1.1/s) in the AP2PL fluorescence (Fig. 2, top trace). As a control phosphorylation experiment, 10 μm ATP was added to the enzyme preparation not treated with AP2PL, which resulted in a more rapid phosphorylation (60/s) to give 1.5 nmol of phosphoenzyme/mg of protein (Fig. 2,inset, closed circles). To investigate the relationship between AcP-induced phosphorylation and fluorescence change (Table I), various concentrations of AcP were added to the AP2PL enzyme. Each addition of 0.1, 1, and 3 mm induced a monophasic increase in AP2PL fluorescence, 0.5, 1.2, and 3.2/s to an extent of 1.6, 3.9, and 4.2%, respectively (Fig. 3 A). The addition of 1 mm [32P]AcP induced a more rapid phosphorylation (3/s) than a fluorescence change to give 1.3 nmol of phosphoenzyme/mg of protein as has been reported previously (32Tsuda T. Kaya S. Yokoyama T. Taniguchi K. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1997; 834: 186-193Crossref PubMed Scopus (5) Google Scholar). Neither a biphasic AP2PL fluorescence change, such as that observed by the addition of ATP (Fig. 2, top and second trace) nor a biphasic increase was observed by the addition of various concentrations of AcP (Fig. 3, A and B). The concentration dependence of AcP on both the extent of phosphorylation and fluorescence change appeared to be nearly the same (K 0.5 = ∼0.1 mm) as shown (Fig. 3 B, open circles and triangles). However the rate constant for the monophasic fluorescence changes increased linearly with an increase in the concentration of AcP (Fig. 3 B, closed triangles). The apparent second order rate constant (k +1) for the AcP of the enzyme form with a high AP2PL fluorescence, as estimated from the slope, was found to be 1.2 × 103m−1 s−1. The dissociation rate constant (k −1) and the dissociation constant (K d =k −1/k +1) estimated from the intercept and the ratio was 0.4 s−1 and 0.3 mm, respectively. The present experiments show directly that the maximum amount of steady state phosphorylation of Na+,K+-ATPase is approximately 0.5 mol/mol of α-chain. The maximum amount of ATP or its analogues binding to the enzyme was shown to be the same, ∼1 mol/mol of α-chain (37Matsui H. Hayashi Y. Homareda H. Taguchi M. Curr. Top. Membr. Transp. 1983; 19: 141-148Google Scholar) or nearly the same (Ref. 20Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar; see also Table I of Ref. 27Yamazaki A. Kaya S. Tsuda T. Araki Y. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1994; 116: 1360-1369Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar) to that of ouabain-enzyme complex. Present data are consistent with our previous data, which showed that the ratio of the maximum amount of ouabain-enzyme complex to that of phosphoenzyme was ∼2 and was independent of the specific activity of the enzyme preparations from dog kidney purified with SDS (2000–2750 μmol of Pi/mg of protein/h) or from pig kidney purified with sodium deoxycholate-NaI (500–1200 μmol of Pi/mg of protein/h) (27Yamazaki A. Kaya S. Tsuda T. Araki Y. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1994; 116: 1360-1369Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar). It has been reported that pig kidney Na+,K+-ATPase preparations contained ∼10% heterogeneity (38Jensen J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1992; 1110: 81-87Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar). This value is too small to explain half of the site reactivities described below. The Lys-480 is conserved in various Na+,K+-ATPase α-chains (39Xu K. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 5764-5772Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar). The amino acid sequence analysis of the α-chains of pig kidney enzymes showed that nearly all the sequence started with Gly-1, which also excluded proteolytic breakdown of the α-chain to produce 50% heterogeneity (not shown). The present data showed half-site phosphorylation by ATP and AcP, respectively, and half-site reactivity to AP2PL (a quarter-site phosphorylation by ATP after the half-site modification by AP2PL), while they showed full-site ouabain binding capacity from Pi with Mg2+ (27Yamazaki A. Kaya S. Tsuda T. Araki Y. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1994; 116: 1360-1369Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar), ATP-sensitive full-site reactivity toward FITC and nearly full-site ATP binding capacity, respectively (20Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). From these data it can be concluded that Mg2+- and Na+-dependent phosphorylation from ATP or AcP under steady state conditions occurred on only half of the Asp-369 residues in the α-chains of the membrane-bound Na+,K+-ATPase. It is possible, but not likely, that these preparations used were 50% denatured or contained nonfunctional enzymes with respect to the phosphorylation. This possibility can be rejected based on the following data. For similar pig kidney enzyme preparations, the ratio of the maximum amount of phosphoenzyme formed from paranitrophenylphosphate and from ATP under a steady state condition was ∼2 (27Yamazaki A. Kaya S. Tsuda T. Araki Y. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1994; 116: 1360-1369Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar). A large transient increase in the amount of phosphoenzyme compared with that under a steady state level occurred after the addition of high concentrations of ATP (40Peluffo R.D. Rossi R.C. Garrahan P.J. Rega A.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 1051-1056Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Chymotryptic digestion increased in the amount of phosphoenzymes (41Liu G. Xie Z. Modyyanof N.N. Askari A. FEBS Lett. 1996; 390: 323-326Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar). These data can be explained, based on full-site phosphorylation, which occurred under those conditions as the result of a decrease or disruption of subunit-interactions (23Askari A. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1987; 19: 359-374Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar, 31Hayashi Y. Kameyama K. Kobayashi T. Hagiwara E. Shinji N. Takagi T. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1997; 834: 19-29Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar, 41Liu G. Xie Z. Modyyanof N.N. Askari A. FEBS Lett. 1996; 390: 323-326Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar). The Na+-bound AP2PL and AP2PL-FITC enzyme showed a 2 order of magnitude reduced affinity for ATP in the presence of CDTA (20Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar) but the addition of ∼μm ATP in the presence of 4 mmMg2+ to the Na+-bound enzymes clearly induced dynamic AP2PL fluorescence changes that were independent of FITC treatment (Fig. 2 and Table I). The issue of the meaning of the ATP-induced AP2PL fluorescence change of AP2PL and AP2PL-FITC enzymes (Fig. 2 A and Table I) is an interesting one. The presence of ATP, Mg2+, and Na+ is a prerequisite for dynamic reversible AP2PL fluorescence change as reported previously (17Kaya S. Tsuda T. Hagiwara K. Fukui T. Taniguchi K. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 7419-7422Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). ATP could not be replaced with either a nonhydrolyzable ATP analogue, AMP-PNP, or ADP (Fig. 2). The increase of apparent turnover of Na+-ATPase after AP2PL or AP2PL-FITC treatment suggests ATP hydrolysis without phosphorylation (Table I). No significant binding of ATP, ADP, or Pi to the AP2PL-FITC enzyme was detected in the presence of ATP, Mg2+, Na+, and pyruvate kinase (20Tsuda T. Kaya S. Funatsu H. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1998; 123: 169-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). These data suggest that the AP2PL fluorescence change reflects a conformational state of the enzyme immediately after ATP hydrolysis rather than that of the ATP-bound enzyme containing Mg2+ and Na+ or an enzyme-phosphate complex. For both AP2PL and AP2PL-FITC enzymes, it would be useful to follow not only ATP, but also AcP-induced conformational events near the ATP binding or phosphorylation domain of the enzyme. The half- and full-site reactivities described above appear to be consistent with a diprotomer model of the enzyme (Fig. 4 A). However the AP2PL enzyme showed a quarter-site phosphorylation/α-chain from ATP followed by slower AP2PL fluorescence change (Table I, Figs. 1 B and 2). The enzyme also showed half-site phosphorylation by AcP followed by slower AP2PL fluorescence change (Table I and Fig. 3). These data are consistent with a tetrameric model (Fig. 4 B). Previous data also supported a quarter-site reactivity to show that only half of the phosphoenzyme formed, which was equal to 0.25 mol/α-chain, was split rapidly by acetate (10Taniguchi K. Tosa H. Suzuki K. Kamo Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 12943-12947Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and only half of the ADP-sensitive phosphoenzyme was split by p-nitrophenol to synthesizep-nitrophenylphosphate (27Yamazaki A. Kaya S. Tsuda T. Araki Y. Hayashi Y. Taniguchi K. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1994; 116: 1360-1369Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar). Affinity modification with an ATP analog is reported to occur to the extent of 1 mol/4 protomers (21Dzhandzhugazyan K. Modyanov N. Glynn I. Ellory C. Sodium Pump. Company of Biologists Ltd, Cambridge, United Kingdom1985: 129-134Google Scholar). It has been also suggested that if only half of the protomers are phosphorylated, the ligand-induced cooperativities of the equilibrium binding data indicated that the functional unit is a tetramer of αβ-protomers (23Askari A. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1987; 19: 359-374Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). Model B explains the fact (Fig. 2) that 10 μm ATP induced a quarter-site phosphorylation of the AP2PL enzyme (47/s) at one of two nonmodified α-chains and that ATP then induced a rapid decrease (29/s) in one AP2PL-modified α-chain and a slow increase (1.1/s) in another AP2PL-modified α-chain. One may ask that subunit interactions are not prerequisite for Na+,K+-ATPase activity, since the AP2PL enzyme still retained ∼50% of Na+,K+-ATPase activity in spite of a 50% reduction in phosphorylation capacity from ATP (Table I). Although further experiments are required, one explanation is that ATP induced the AP2PL fluorescence change in the AP2PL-modified α-chain and the resulting conformational state might be sufficient to allow subunit interaction, and in turn, to permit ATP hydrolysis in non-modified α-chains. Recently, the dimeric interaction of αβ-protomers was detected by a cross-linking reagent (23Askari A. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1987; 19: 359-374Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar, 28Sarvazyan N.A. Modyanov N.N. Askari A. J. Biol. Acad. Sci. 1997; 834: 19-29Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). The coexistence of both high and low affinity sites for ATP in time and in different locations was proposed (26Schoner W. Dietrich Steinkopff Verlag GmbH & Co. KG, Darmstadt, Germany1994: 332-341Crossref Google Scholar). The present data extend these with respect to showing that the maximum phosphorylation/mol of α-chain for ATP or AcP was ∼0.5 and that Mg2+-Na+-bound AP2PL enzyme accepted ATP, inducing a quarter-site phosphorylation followed by two different AP2PL fluorescence changes. Quarter-, half-, and full-site reactivities support the hypothesis that the functional unit of membrane-bound Na+,K+-ATPase is a tetraprotomer, composed of αβ protomers. TherpsB-tsf-x operon of Spiroplasma citri encodes ribosomal protein S2 and elongation factor Ts, two components of the translational apparatus, and an unidentified X protein. A potential DNA-binding site (a 20-base pair (bp) inverted repeat sequence) is located at the 3′ end of rpsB. Southwestern analysis of S. citriproteins, with a 30-bp double-stranded oligonucleotide probe (IRS), containing the 20-bp inverted repeat sequence and the genomic flanking sequences, detected an IRS-binding protein of 46 kDa (P46). P46 protein, which displays preferential affinity for the IRS, was purified from S. citri by a combination of affinity and gel filtration chromatographies. The native form of P46 seems to be homomultimeric as estimated by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis analysis and gel filtration. A 3.5-kilobase pair S. citriDNA fragment comprising the P46 gene and flanking sequences was cloned and sequenced. Sequence analysis of this DNA fragment indicated that the P46 gene is located within the S10-spc operon of S. citri at the position of the gene coding for ribosomal protein L29 in the known S10-spc operons. The similarity between the N-terminal domain of P46 and the L29 ribosomal protein family and the presence of a 46-kDa IRS-binding protein in S. citri ribosomes indicated that P46 is the L29 ribosomal protein of S. citri. We suggest that P46 is a bifunctional protein with an L29 N-terminal domain and a C-terminal domain involved in IRS binding. TherpsB-tsf-x operon of Spiroplasma citri encodes ribosomal protein S2 and elongation factor Ts, two components of the translational apparatus, and an unidentified X protein. Spiroplasmas are wall-free bacteria belonging to the class Mollicutes, a group of microorganisms phylogenetically related to Gram-positive bacteria with low guanine + cytosine contents (1Weisburg W.G. Tully J.G. Rose D.L. Petzel J.P. Oyaizu H. Yang D. Mandelco L. Sechrest J. Lawrence T.G. Van Etten J. Maniloff J. Woese C.R. J. Bacteriol. 1989; 171: 6455-6467Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Sequence analysis (70Le Dantec, L., Bové, J. M., and Saillard C. (1998)Curr. Microbiol., in pressGoogle Scholar) of a 6.8-kbp1 DNA fragment (GenBankTM accession number AF012877) of the phytopathogenic mollicute Spiroplasma citri (2Saglio P. Lhospital M. Laflèche D. Dupont G. Bové J.M. Tully J.G. Freundt E.A. Int. J. Syst. Bacteriol. 1973; 23: 191-204Crossref Scopus (196) Google Scholar) made it possible to identify eight putative ORFs that encode ribosomal protein S2, elongation factor Ts, spiralin, 6-phosphofructokinase, pyruvate kinase, and three unidentified proteins (A, B,and X) (Fig. 1). Ribosomal protein S2 and the translational elongation factor Ts (Ef-Ts), respectively, encoded by rpsB and tsf genes, are both components of the translational apparatus in prokaryotes. These genes are adjacent in Escherichia coli (3An G. Bendiak D.S. Mamelak L.A. Friesen J.D. Nucleic Acids Res. 1981; 9: 4163-4172Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar, 4Bendiak D.S. Friesen J.D. In E. coli, rpsB and tsf form a single transcriptional unit, and an attenuation mechanism was proposed to explain the 1 to 3 ratio of Ef-Ts to S2 (3An G. Bendiak D.S. Mamelak L.A. Friesen J.D. Nucleic Acids Res. 1981; 9: 4163-4172Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). In B. subtilisa potential terminator is found between rpsB and tsf. In S. citri, the absence of a rho-independent termination signal in the spacer region betweenrpsB and tsf, and between tsf and x, indicates that rpsB, tsf, and X might represent a single transcriptional unit. Transcriptional analyses of rpsB, tsf, and x genes of S. citri have recently revealed two different transcripts (70Le Dantec, L., Bové, J. M., and Saillard C. (1998)Curr. Microbiol., in pressGoogle Scholar), one corresponding to therpsB/tsf/x operon and the second torpsB alone. These results suggested that a regulatory mechanism may act at the transcriptional level at the spacer region between rpsB and tsf. The only “regulatory” like sequence found in the rpsB-tsf region is an inverted repeat sequence at the 3′ end of rpsB (Fig. 1). This inverted repeat sequence is 20 bp long and represents two turns of helical DNA. It could be a binding site for a regulatory DNA-binding protein (8Pabo C.O. Sauer R.T. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1984; 53: 293-321Crossref PubMed Scopus (1022) Google Scholar, 9Harrison S.C. Aggarwal A.K. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1990; 59: 933-969Crossref PubMed Scopus (494) Google Scholar). In the study reported here, we have purified, by a combination of affinity and gel filtration chromatographies, a 46-kDa protein (P46) that displays preferential binding to a 30-bp double-stranded oligonucleotide containing the inverted repeat sequence. The gene coding for P46 has been cloned and sequenced. Sequence analysis has revealed significant similarities between the N-terminal part of P46 and the L29 eubacterial ribosomal protein family. Surprisingly, theS. citri protein is much larger than its eubacterial homologs, and the C-terminal domain of P46 shows significant similarities with the DNA-binding histone H1-like proteins found in some bacterial species. These results suggest a bifunctional role for P46. The protein could act as a ribosomal protein but also as a DNA-binding protein with a potential regulatory function. Crude extracts were prepared from S. citri strain R8A2 (ATCC 27556) cultivated in 5 to 10 liters of SP4 medium (10Tully J.G. Whitcomb R.F. Clark H.F. Williamson D.L. Science. 1977; 195: 892-894Crossref PubMed Scopus (237) Google Scholar) at 32 °C. Cells from exponential growth phase were harvested by centrifugation at 17,000 × gfor 40 min, washed with phosphate-buffered saline containing 70 g/liter sorbitol, and frozen at −20 °C overnight. Cells were then thawed on ice, resuspended in 10 to 30 ml of binding buffer BB (10 mmHEPES, pH 7.9, 50 mm KCl, 1 mm EDTA, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 12.5% glycerol) containing 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, and disrupted by sonication (5/10-s pulses, 50 watts, 0 °C, 1 min sonication, and 1 min on ice alternatively, 8 to 10 times with a Vibracell sonicator). Mixture was cleared by centrifugation at 12,000 × gfor 20 min; the pellet was discarded, and the supernatant was directly loaded onto heparin chromatography column or frozen at −70 °C for storage. The protein concentration of the supernatant, assayed by the Bradford procedure (11Bradford M.M. Anal. Biochem. 1976; 72: 248-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (217548) Google Scholar) using the Bio-Rad Protein Assay Kit with bovine serum albumin as a standard, was in the range of 1–10 mg/ml. The method used for Southwestern analysis is a modification of previously described “protein blotting” method (12Bowen B. Steinberg J. Laemmli U.K. Weintraub H. Nucleic Acids Res. 1980; 8: 1-21Crossref PubMed Scopus (448) Google Scholar). Crude or purified proteins were resolved by SDS-PAGE on 10% polyacrylamide gel using standard procedures (13Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (207538) Google Scholar). After electrophoresis, proteins were electroblotted (14Towbin H. Stahelin T. Gordon J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1979; 76: 4350-4354Crossref PubMed Scopus (44939) Google Scholar) to nitrocellulose membranes (C extra, Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) for 45 min at 8 watts in transfer buffer (25 mm Tris base, 190 mm glycine, and 15% methanol) using a semi-dry transfer apparatus (Fastblot Biometra). Membranes were dried 15 min at 37 °C and blocked for 60 min at 26 °C in buffer S (BB buffer containing 0.02% Ficoll, 0.02% polyvinyl pyrrolidone, and 0.02% bovine serum albumin). Membranes were incubated in 10 ml of S buffer containing 106 cpm/ml end-labeled specific IRS probe. This probe is the synthetic double-stranded oligonucleotide (5′-GGATTTGCTTTACCAAAAGCAAAAAAGCTG-3′ and 3′-CCTAAACGAAATGGTTTTCGTTTTTTCGAC-5′) containing the inverted repeat sequence (Fig. 1). It was end-labeled with [γ-32P]ATP (ICN Biochemicals) using T4 polynucleotide kinase and purified using a Sephadex G-25 column (15Sambrook J. Fritsch E.F. Maniatis T. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. 2nd Ed. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1989Google Scholar). Incubations were at 26 °C for 60 min in screw-capped glass tubes with gentle rotation in rotating hybridization oven (Robbins Scientific), followed by three washes of 15 min in S buffer. The blots were then exposed 1–12 h for autoradiography. Preferential affinity of P46 for the IRS sequence was examined by competition experiments; 15 min prior to the addition of the radiolabeled IRS, blots were incubated with a 200-fold molar excess of unlabeled IRS (specific competitor) or with a 200-fold molar excess of an unlabeled double-stranded oligonucleotide that does not contain the inverted repeat sequence (5′-GGTTATTAAGTTATCGATTT-3′ and 3′-CCAATAATTCAATAGCTAAA-5′) (nonspecific competitor). After addition of the radiolabeled IRS to these hybridization mixtures containing the competitors, the incubation was for 1 h as described above. Column operations were carried out by using a Bio-Pilot Scale FPLC system (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). About 70 mg of total proteins were loaded onto HiTrap heparin column (1 ml, Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) equilibrated at a flow rate of 1 ml/min with ice-cold BB buffer. The column was washed with ice-cold BB buffer until the 280-nm absorbance reading returned to the base line, and proteins were eluted with a 20-ml linear gradient of 50 mm to 1 m KCl in BB buffer. Fractions of 0.3 ml were collected, and 10–50-μl aliquots from each fraction were analyzed on SDS-PAGE gels by Coomassie Blue staining and tested for the presence of IRS-binding proteins by Southwestern blot analyses. Fractions containing IRS-binding proteins were loaded on a gel filtration chromatography column without freezing. Remaining fractions were stored frozen at −70 °C. Fractions (200 μl) collected from the affinity chromatography containing IRS-binding proteins were loaded onto an FPLC Superose 12 column (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) equilibrated with running buffer (BB buffer containing 200 mm KCl) at a flow rate of 0.2 ml/min. The column was eluted at 0.2 ml/min with running buffer; and 0.2-ml fractions were collected, and 10–100-μl aliquots of each fraction were analyzed on SDS-PAGE gels by Coomassie Blue staining and tested for the presence of IRS-binding proteins by Southwestern analysis. Column calibration was performed using blue dextran 2000 (for void volume), catalase (232 kDa), aldolase (158 kDa), bovine serum albumin (67 kDa), ovalbumin (43 kDa), chymotrypsinogen A (25 kDa), and ribonuclease A (13.7 kDa) (low molecular weight gel filtration calibration kit from Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). Biochem. 1979; 96: 263-278Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar). P46 band was excised and brought to near dryness under vacuum. After proteolytic digestion with endopeptidase Lys-C, three peptides, designated P1, P2, and P3, were sequenced on an Applied Biosystems 473A protein sequencer. Standard procedures in molecular biology were used for preparation of plasmid DNA, restriction enzyme digestion, DNA agarose gel electrophoresis, DNA ligation, and transformation of E. coli (15Sambrook J. Fritsch E.F. Maniatis T. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. 2nd Ed. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1989Google Scholar). The codon usage of S. citri,based on previously sequenced genes (17Bové J.M. Clin. Infect. Dis. 1993; 17: 10-31Crossref PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar), was used to reduce degeneration of the primers. PCR amplification was performed for 40 cycles in a DNA thermal cycler (Perkin-Elmer), using 40 cycles, each of 1 min at 92 °C, 1 min at 37 °C, 1 min at 72 °C. The primer pair, P46-2, 5′-GAAAA(C/T)AC(A/T)GC(A/T)AT(A/T)AA(C/T)GT(A/T)AA-3′ (a sense oligonucleotide corresponding to the C-terminal end of internal peptide sequence P2, KNSGENTAINVK), and P46-1c, 5′-TT(C/T)CA(A/G)TT(A/T)GT(A/C/T)CC(A/G)TA-3′ (an antisense oligonucleotide corresponding to the N-terminal end of internal peptide sequence P1, KEYTYGTNWK), was found to drive the amplification of a 0.7-kbp DNA fragment. This fragment was cloned into the pTAG vector (R & D Systems) that has complementary T overhangs, suitable for ligation of PCR fragments. This fragment was sequenced using T7 sequencing kit (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) together with pTAG SEQ 5′ and pTAG SEQ 3′ primers (R & D Systems). The insert was excised from the vector, separated on agarose gel, purified by the GeneClean Kit (Bio 101, La Jolla, CA), random primer-labeled with [α-32P]ATP (ICN Biochemicals), purified on a Sephadex G-50 column (15Sambrook J. Fritsch E.F. Maniatis T. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. 2nd Ed. Biol. 1975; 98: 503-517Crossref PubMed Scopus (21490) Google Scholar) with S. citrirestricted genomic DNA. A 3.5-kbp EcoRI DNA fragment was detected. The probe was then used to screen an S. citrigenomic library, constructed in E. coli XL1 Blue by cloningEcoRI-restricted DNA fragments into plasmid pBS+ (Stratagene Cloning Systems). One positive clone containing the 3.5-kbpEcoRI insert was selected. S. citri cells were ground with alumina and suspended in buffer A (10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.8, 10 mmmagnesium acetate, 60 mm NH4Cl, 6 mm 2-mercaptoethanol) containing DNase I at 2 μg/ml. The extract was centrifuged at 22,000 × g for 30 min to remove cell debris and then at 33,000 × g for 30 min to obtain the S-30 fraction. The S-30 fraction was centrifuged at 105,000 × g for 2 h to sediment the ribosomes. The supernatant solution (S-105) was aspirated, and the ribosomes were suspended in buffer A and were washed by centrifuging again at 105,000 × g for 2 h. The supernatant fluid was decanted and discarded, and the ribosomes were suspended in buffer A. Enriched ribosomal fraction was aliquoted an stored at −70 °C or used directly in Southwestern experiments. Final protein concentration was 0.7 mg/ml in the ribosome fraction and 1.5 mg/ml in the S-105 fraction. 50-μl aliquots of ribosome fraction and S-105 fraction were tested for the presence of IRS-binding proteins by Southwestern analysis (see above). We describe here the purification, preliminary characterization, and identification of an S. citri protein that displays preferential binding affinity for a 30-bp oligonucleotide containing the 20-bp inverted repeat sequence present at the 3′-OH end of rpsB and preceding tsf (Fig. 1). The 30-bp sequence will be designated IRS. Crude extract of S. citri cells obtained by sonication in binding buffer BB, as described under “Experimental Procedures,” was applied onto a heparin-agarose affinity column. Bound proteins were eluted with a linear gradiant of 0.05–1 m KCl. Protein concentration was monitored by absorbance at 280 nm (Fig. 2 A). Aliquots of the eluted fractions were first analyzed by SDS-PAGE electrophoresis and Coomassie Blue staining (Fig. 2 B). Detection of IRS-binding proteins was carried out by Southwestern blots (12Bowen B. Steinberg J. Laemmli U.K. Weintraub H. Nucleic Acids Res. 1980; 8: 1-21Crossref PubMed Scopus (448) Google Scholar, 27Miskimins W.K. Roberts M.P. McClelland A. Ruddle F.H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. Science. 1988; 239: 1531-1534Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). In short, proteins were resolved on SDS-PAGE, transferred on a nitrocellulose sheet, and incubated with radiolabeled IRS. After washing, IRS-binding proteins were detected by autoradiography. Southwestern analysis of eluted fractions detected a predominant IRS-binding protein of 46 kDa (P46) (Fig. 2 C) eluted at approximately 0.37–0.42 mKCl as indicated in Fig. 2 A. Two other minor IRS-binding protein species of approximately 25 and 38 kDa were detected in fractions 31–32 and 36, respectively. Part of the binding activity was lost after freezing/thawing cycles; therefore active fractions were used for further experiments immediately after preparation. To determine if the P46 protein displays some preferential affinity for the IRS sequence, we have used Southwestern competition assay. Aliquots of fraction F29 containing P46 protein eluted from the heparin column (Fig. 2) were resolved on three separate tracks (Fig. 3) by 10% SDS-PAGE and subjected to Southwestern analysis. Membranes were incubated with radiolabeled IRS (Fig. 3 lane A) or with radiolabeled IRS in the presence of cold competitors (Fig. 3, lanes B and C). Binding of radiolabeled IRS to P46 was not significantly reduced by a 200-fold molar excess of a non-labeled double-stranded oligonucleotide (Fig. 3,lane B), which does not contain the inverted repeat sequence, as compared with the IRS binding in the absence of competitor (Fig. 3, lane A). Competition by a 200-fold molar excess of non-labeled IRS reduced dramatically, or made undetectable, the binding of radiolabeled IRS (Fig. 3, lane C). These results strongly suggested that P46 exhibits preferential binding affinity for IRS. In a second step toward P46 purification, 200-μl aliquot of fraction F29 containing P46 protein retrieved from the heparin-agarose affinity column (Fig. 2) was loaded onto an FPLC Superose 12 column. Proteins were eluted at 0.2 ml/min with running buffer. Protein concentration was monitored by absorbance at 280 nm (Fig. 4 A). Aliquots of eluted fractions were analyzed by SDS-PAGE, and proteins were stained with Coomassie Blue (Fig. 4 B). IRS binding proteins were analyzed by Southwestern blots (Fig. 4 C). Almost all of the P46 IRS binding activity was present in fractions 26–28, and, as judged by SDS-PAGE and Coomassie Blue staining, P46 was practically the only protein seen in these fractions. Comparison of the elution time of P46 from the Superose column with that of molecular mass markers including catalase (232 kDa), aldolase (158 kDa), bovine serum albumin (67 kDa), ovalbumin (43 kDa), chymotrypsinogen A (25 kDa), and ribonuclease A (13.7 kDa) indicated that P46 eluted at a position consistent with a molecular mass of approximately 180 kDa. This suggest that the native form of P46 is a homomultimer. To characterize further P46 we cloned its gene. First, P46 was partially sequenced. To that purpose an aliquot of fraction F27 containing P46 from the gel filtration purification step (Fig. 4) was resolved by 10% SDS-PAGE, and proteins were stained with amido black (16Wilson C. Anal. Biochem. 1979; 96: 263-278Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar). The P46 band was excised from the gel and submitted to endoproteolysis with Endo Lys-C. The proteolytic products were separated by reversed phase high performance liquid chromatography and three peptides (P1, P2, and P3) were sequenced. None of these sequences exhibited homology to any known protein sequence available in the data bases. Amino acid sequences of peptides P1 (KEYTYGTNWK) and P2 (KNSGENTAINVK) were used to design two pairs of degenerated primers in order to amplify by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) part of the gene of the P46 protein. An amplified DNA fragment of 700 bp was generated using the P462/P461c primer pair (see “Experimental Procedures”), cloned into pTAG vector, and sequenced. Sequence analysis of the cloned DNA fragment revealed that the amino acid sequence predicted from the amplified product contained the N-terminal sequence of the P1 peptide and the entire sequence of the P3 peptide (KIDLELK), confirming that this amplified product was generated from the P46 gene. Cloning of the full-length P46 gene was undertaken to gain further sequence information. A 3.5-kbp EcoRI S. citriDNA fragment was detected by Southern blot analysis of restricted genomic DNA using the 700-bp DNA fragment as a probe. Screening of anEcoRI S. citri genomic library with this probe yielded a clone containing a 3.5-kbp insert which was sequenced. Sequence analysis (details are described under “Experimental Procedures”) of the 3.5-kbp insert gave the following results. Authenticity of the insert was confirmed by perfect matches with the sequence of the three peptides (P1, P2, and P3) derived from purified P46 (Fig. 5). The molecular mass deduced from the ORF of the cloned P46 gene was 37 kDa, whereas its apparent molecular mass in SDS-PAGE was 46 kDa. Sequence similarities between deduced amino acid sequences of the insert and protein data bases (see Table I) showed that the gene coding for the P46 protein was located within a ribosomal protein operon corresponding to the S10 and spc operons of E. coli (29Post L.E. Porcine pepsin proteolysis of the hexapeptide Leu-Ser-p-nitro-Phe-Nle-Ala-Leu-OMe (where OMe = methoxy and Nle = norleucine) in the presence of dipeptide Leu-Leu synthesizes a new hexapeptide Leu-Ser-p-nitro-Phe-Leu-Leu. Contrary to transpeptidation kinetics of other proteases, which depend upon an acyl-enzyme intermediate, the time course for pepsin-catalyzed transpeptidation displays a distinct lag before reaching a steady-state reaction velocity. Moreover, this lag is coupled to burst kinetics for the formation of proteolytic products, Leu-Ser-p-nitro-Phe and Nle-Ala-Leu-OMe. The lag requires that free Leu-Ser-p-nitro-Phe accumulate in the reaction medium during the lag phase and subsequently rebind for transpeptidation. Consistent with this dissociative kinetic mechanism are normal solvent isotope effects on formation of the proteolytic products Leu-Ser-p-nitro-Phe (v H /v D = 2.2 ± 0.2) and Nle-Ala-Leu-OMe (v H /v D = 1.8 ± 0.1) as opposed to an inverse effect on the formation of the transpeptidation product Leu-Ser-p-nitro-Phe-Leu-Leu (v H /v D = 0.40 ± 0.09). Because proteolysis is slower in D2O but transpeptidation is faster, the isotopically sensitive step must occurafter release of both products of proteolysis, which precludes putative acyl-enzyme covalent intermediates. Isotopically enhanced transpeptidation is a new type of isotope effect but one that is consistent with the Uni Bi iso-mechanism previously postulated on the basis of solvent isotope effects on V maxbut not on V max/K m(Rebholz, K. L., and Northrop, D. B. (1991) Biochem. Biophys Res. Commun. 179, 65–69) and confirmed by solvent isotope effects on the onset of inhibition by pepstatin (Cho, Y.-K., Rebholz, K. L., and Northrop, D. B. (1994)Biochemistry 33, 9637–9642). As a new biochemical mechanism for peptide bond synthesis that has a potential for applications in biotechnology, it is here proposed that the energy necessary to drive peptide synthesis from free peptides comes from the sizable free energy drop associated with rehydration of the active site of pepsin in 55 m water.
